byline.contributor: Alain Delaquérière and Nate Schweber contributed research.
byline.original: By RANDY KENNEDY, EVE M. KAHN and PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

abstract: Connecticut man John Ryan comes forward as seller after Rago Arts and Auction Center cancels controversial sale of art and artifacts made in internment camps by Japanese-Americans during World War II; Ryan inherited collection from his father, who acquired it under disputed circumstances from daughter of Allen Hendershott Eaton who was given items by internees when he was writing book on subject in 1950s.
lead_paragraph: After an auction of artifacts from Japanese-American internment camps was called off, the seller stepped forward to explain his reasoning.

headline.main: Seller in Canceled Internment-Camp Auction Comes Forward
headline.print_headline: Seller in Disputed Auction Comes Forward

snippet: After an auction of artifacts from Japanese-American internment camps was called off, the seller stepped forward to explain his reasoning.
